reviewText: Starship Troopers 3 / B0018CWWA0I really love the Starship Troopers franchise for the over-the-top satire of a jingoistic, military-worshiping society that fails to comprehend while it struggles for "the survival of humanity" that, in fact, they have no humanity left.I was looking forward intensely to Starship Troopers 3 and was initially pleased to see the movie start right out with the jingoistic commercials, easily my favorite draw of the parodies. However, disappointment quickly set in. This movie is, for all its violence and satire, painfully boring. The dialogue is leaden, and the plot makes no sense whatsoever - as has been pointed out elsewhere, it is ridiculous that the electric fence had no backup whatsoever, and the fact that this isn't explained or acknowledged just feels like lazy filmmaking. A few simple tweaks could have made these faults part of the parody (i.e., they were so over-confident in their abilities that they didn't bother with backups, which would be a nice little chunk of hubris to chew on) but they just couldn't be bothered.The plot, acting, and direction all felt terribly lazy, and this movie feels like it was mailed in for a quick cash-in on the name.This movie has closed captions for the hearing impaired.~ Ana Mardoll

reviewText: My Rating:  3.75 out of 5The Good Things*Has a good amount of action and special effects.*Very good photography.*Better production quality than "Starship Troopers 2." Contains some bloody violence and nudity (but it's not quite as bad as the last two films).*Despite the slick-looking production value, it's still not up to par with the first film, and can therefore be seen as inferior (I don't think it's too bad, though).  Also, some special effects do look a little fake."Starship Troopers 2" was completely dull; I was pleased to see that number 3 returned to the basic fundamentals of the first original film.  Aside from bringing back Johnny Rico (Casper Van Dien), they've also brought back the battles, the satire, the gung-ho attitude, and consequently, the fun. reviewText: I've read Heinlein's book many times. The first Starship Troopers movie had only a passing connection to the book, yet I still enjoyed it a lot. The second movie was just low budget trash ... mostly voices in the dark from start to finish.They made some effort with this movie, yet failed miserably. Caspar Van Dien is back, but in a very limited role for only the first half hour or so of the film. Jolene Blalock from "Star Trek: Enterprise" is more the central star. For some reason, her make up is so poorly done throughout this film that she really looks bad, and that's hard to accomplish.The acting is bad throughout. Van Dien tries, but without really anything to work with, his performance doesn't sell. None of the other performers is able to rise above the trite lines they are given, either. Special effects are a MAJOR step down from the first movie. Everything looks cheaply done ... sets, effects, make up, the script, and on and on.In "Starship Troopers", we were given a view of a paternalistic, propaganda based society that had nothing to do with Heinlein's story. In this, the society has made a left turn into extreme fascism, something VERY far from Heinlein's book. It was so overplayed that it was offensive.The first part of our story has major characters at a Mobile Infantry base on a farm planet which has been invaded by bugs. Their electric defense fails and the base suffers a major attack. Later some of the main characters (not including Rico) crash land on a remote desert part of the planet. The movie then devolves into a "pick 'em off one at a time trek". The promised powered armor suits (Marauder suits) only make a very brief deus ex machine appearance at the end of the film, and again are not what was depicted in Heinlein's book.When I am predisposed to like a film, but get disgusted early on and never see an improvement, that's a bad sign for any movie. Sadly, this was one of those.
summary: Sadly, just a waste of time

reviewText: Ok, what I just don't get is how is it possible for a movie, even if it is direct to DVD to be so bad?Surely it has to have a bigger budget than most television shows... And yet, it looks like it was made on a shoe string budget!What I'm talking about here is Starship Troopers 3: Marauder.I loved the first movie that came out in 97. I didn't much care for the sequel which of course was direct to video. But then again, it was exactly what I expected. After all, it was made on a low budget and it showed.And it was more of a horror movie than something that belonged in the Starship Trooper's universe. But, I digress.Now take a television series like, oh I don't know... Stargate SG1, Stargate Atlantis, hell even Battlestar Galactica (the re-envisioning, not the original). Each episode must have a minuscule budget compared to that of Marauders... and yet even a season opener or Finale looks a thousand times better!Could someone explain that to me?As per usual here is my disclaimer. I will not give away any spoilers other than what you can see on the trailers that you can find online and elsewhere.WITH TWO EXCEPTIONS! I'll warn you in advance.Ok, the movie is pretty simple. It's a giant bug hunt, with plenty of political satire thrown in for fun.It doesn't work.First spoiler, albeit a minor one.The satire was well played in the first movie, and pretty much non-existent in the second movie. Well, they overdid it in this one.Way too much.Come on, hangings for being against the war? Speaking your mind? If that sort of thing happened for real, well, there would be out and out revolt and civil war. It was humours at times, but they really should have toned it down.Anyhow, back to the bug hunt - there were plenty of bugs to be seen, and it wasn't too badly done, although you'd think that in the eleven years since the first movie that they would use computer technology to make the bugs look even BETTER than the original.Nope. That wasn't the case. It wasn't bad, but come on; I've seen computer animation on the small screen that was better done. And the live interaction with the warrior bugs? Please... it was something right out of an 80's movie, but not as well done!Oh, the acting was so over the top it was laughable. And not in a good way. I feel bad for Casper Van Dien - he was the worst of the bunch, but not by much. Shame that he's been delegated to pretty much nothing but direct to DVD movies...Warning number 2, last spoiler directly ahead...The only thing that I thought was kind of neat in the movie was the introduction of the Marauders... something that was sorely missed in the first movie. You know the thing that made Heinlein's novel a classic... the powered armour.I have to say that is probably where the vast majority of the movie's budget went. Straight into the special effects for the Marauder sequence.And even then it wasn't all that great. Computerized powered armour going up against hordes of alien bugs.You want that sort of action, do yourself a favour and buy or rent the much better Roughnecks: The Starship Troopers Chronicles. A computer animated series that was out back in 1999.Believe it or not, despite my trashing the movie, was wasn't that hard to watch. I guess I simply had high expectations and I was disappointed. After all, look at so many Canadian productions like the Stargate Franchise... you'd think that a direct to DVD movie would have that sort of quality.It just isn't so.As to the special features, it had your ever present commentary with director Ed Neumeier, and actors Casper Van Dien and Jolene Blalock. There was a truly horrible music video `it's a good day to die', as well as two featurettes - The Bugs of Starship Troopers 3 (which wasn't that bad, actually, kind of fun to watch), and Enlist, the Marauders mobile infantry. Sorry, but I didn't watch that one.It's ok, it's worth renting if there isn't anything better to watch.2 out of 5

reviewText: It seemed that this movie was targeted for that age group (13-16 years old) or the director/film maker where that old when they made this crap.  The director's commentary changed my view on the first movie so I thought the director's commentary would change my mind on this one.  Nope, no such luck.  The acting was just so bad that it had me laughing out loud.  The complete insanity of the "general" making a total ass of himself and saying such silly and stupid things made me say "wow" out loud several times.The premise of the first movie was to conclude that in war all governments eventually turn into fascists governments.  When I say "turn into" I don't mean that literally.  Just that they behave and produce those results.  This came directly from the director's mouth during his commentary and that is what he was trying to get across.As I listened to this commentary (there are two of them - one from the film maker and the other from the director/cast) I really didn't get a clear picture of what they were trying to say.  Sure there was the ending where the director was saying that the State will USE religion to their benefit.  If it interferes with them, they will try to eliminate it, if they think they can use it for an advantage then they would.  Regardless of these "messages" that they were trying to convey, it was done in an amateurish and sloppy way.I give sci-fi a GREAT deal of leeway when it comes to suspending belief, however I do have limits.  There was something that did occur to me and it might occur to you too.  The way these people behaved would tend to make me believe that a highly advanced technological society could in fact be extremely sloppy and inefficient.  Anyone that has been in our own military (as I have) would have thought of a million better ways to protect the base and battle these bugs.  Even with our current day weapons, our own military could put down a volume of fire that would annihilate these bugs.  For a society that has been at war with these bugs for the past 10 years would make any government fire the contractor or the advanced weapons division that continues to use those ineffective firearms they use, Marauders at the end notwithstanding.  The level of insubordination in these troopers is amazing given the extreme threat and in some cases carried out punishments.  But I guess that is part of the point; that a totalitarian society might indeed produce armies with methods and leadership that is highly dysfunctional.These are some of the things that come to mind, though you can get that from the first movie without wasting your time on this bad one.  I thought SST 2 was bad and I still think that one is worse than this one, but not by much.

reviewText: At the end of "Starship Troopers" Johnny Rico was a newly minted lieutenant.  Ten years later he's a colonel.  The Federation now employs draconian measures against its citizens, especially ones who question the war against the Bugs.  A singing, dancing, psychic, Sky Marshall (senior military commander) with a messiah complex is at the center of the story as is a stunning pilot (not Denise Richards), an old friend of Rico's, and the romantic issues between them.  We do eventually see the battle suits that were the technological centerpiece of Heinlein's book.Irony should etch lightly from a phrase, not drip from every word.  Gushing from every frame of the movie is definitely out.  The excess of irony was so distracting and adolescent, that it made it very difficult to enjoy what could have been an excellent action movie.The namesake of the movie, the marauder battlesuit was the technical centerpiece of the book, so it was a little disappointing that they were barely included, and more as a gimmick than a theme.Rent, don't buy this one.E. reviewText: Even though ST3 is miles ahead of the "let's hide in a underground bunker for an hour and a half & talk" ST2, it still isn't as good as the original. In fact, it's almost like a pale copy of that first Verhoeven film. Yes, ST3 has all the recruitment inserts, the bugs on the attack, gore o'plenty, and satire reflecting our modern times, but this time around it seems too forced and not nearly as fun.Bringing back from the professional grave Casper Van Dien as Rico and franchise killer Jolene Blalock (from the Star Trek spin-off you never watched), basically ST3 follows the pattern of the military fighting the bug attack, getting their butts kicked, a leader lost, and a new "brain" bug to be found. Sound familiar? Heck, it even has one of those "let's get the cast naked for nudity sake" scenes! But for this go around they added the plot point of religion of God and Christ into the mix and how it's not so favorable in these bug-ridden times. With all this into the film, it's hour & forty-five minute runtime varies from quick-paced to extremely slow in a matter of frames just too often.So for a "direct-to-DVD" film, how's the effects? Varies...bigtime. From the moment you see the first bug you'll realize that the CGI effects for them had weakened considerably. However, within the film they did use some actual puppet effects that look pretty good, but how many times can you see the same rubber head roll across the screen without getting bored with it? This is a movie that goes from theatrical-looking shots to Sci-Fi Original quality very quickly, and that will throw off even the biggest ST fan. And I gotta be honest, if I hear that same phrase "Would you like to know more?" one more time in this, I'm gonna just jump to the nearest bug and impale myself.Overall, this film is an improvement over Number Two, but does question why the first movie was sequelized in the first place. At times being like a purposed parody of the first movie, even going so far as it could be retitled "Bug Movie" with the cast sitting in theatre chairs together on the front cover, it's a somewhat decent way to kill two hours but falls sorta flat on it's own. Stick with the original in your collection and just rent this.(RedSabbath Rating:7.0/10)

reviewText: STARSHIP TROOPERS 3: MARAUDER, third in the series and released in 2008, should thank its lucky stars that the truly horrid HERO OF THE FEDERATION came before it, in effect NOT making MARAUDER the worse entry in the series. Like HERO OF THE FEDERATION, MARAUDER is a direct-to-video release. And while not as cringingly unbearable as HERO OF THE FEDERATION, it's a pretty bad movie. Still, this one tries to instill a sense of humor on the screen, so the satire and campiness earn it some style points.A decade after the events of the firstStarship Troopersmovie, the future of humanity and the Federation is still very much up in the air. The alien bugs keep on pressing. Johnny Rico (Casper Van Dien), now a grizzled veteran and a Colonel, is still doing his part. Except he still tends to go his own way, instead of playing party politics. This lands him in trouble with a former friend, now an officious General. Court martialed and about to be hanged, Rico is given a last-second reprieve when he's offered command of a covert mission, the objective of which is to rescue troopers stranded on OM-1, a quarantined bug planet which houses possibly the most dangerous bug of all.Oh, man, STARSHIP TROOPERS 3: MARAUDER. So bad it's funny, and with enough cheese to get a decent wine tasting under your belt. Given, the budget is very meager. So right away you lose that epic scale shown in the first film. The special effects are, naturally, less than stellar. Explosions which won't wow anyone, cheap-looking shots of Federation vessels in space, gore which is more hokey than gory, and bugs which aren't convincing. The bugs here look like creatures on loan from Mighty Morphin' Power Rangers or, perhaps more aptly, from theRoughnecks - The Starship Troopers Chronicles - The Complete Campaignsanimated series. Not to knock the Roughnecks cartoon, because that was pretty awesome. But there's a difference between CG work in a cartoon and the CG in a live action flick. And, really, when the danger doesn't look real, how can you invest in the peril?The film title "Marauder" refers to the code name given to Rico's seven-man crew tapped to undertake the secret ops to OM-1. They get to gear up in the latest line of mobile infantry armor. Thing is, these gynormous armor suits only show up the last few minutes of the film, and they end up being more anticlimactic than anything else.And you can't blame the tiny budget on the dubious story and script. And the acting? Baaaad, brother, it's bad. Casper Van Dien, not about to ever win an acting award, is still the best actor here, which says something about the rest of the cast. But the film could've definitely used more of Johnny Rico in action and less of Jolene Blalock and her very exasperating group on the bug planet. I had some hopes for Jolene, she of the sexy Vulcan role inStar Trek Enterprise - The Complete First Season. But, it turns out, she wasn't good, either. By the way, after her years playing the stoic T'pol, it startles me to bits to see her crack a smile, let alone laugh. But whatever good will she'd accrued during the film evaporated with her ridiculous final 15 or so minutes on screen.Other than bringing back Johnny Rico, the thing that comes close to (but not quite) making MARAUDER watchable are the satiric elements. The FedNet just keeps on churning out those optimistic, jingoistic wartime propaganda. There are even scheduled hangings of Federation traitors broadcasted on air. You don't have to be a deep thinker to get all the not-so-veiled references to certain topical issues. Politics, religion, nationalism, the war on Iraq. Check, check, check, and check. They're delivered hammily and heavy-handedly, yes, but, here and there, they are insidiously enjoyable.To my shame, I also got a kick out of Sky Marshal Anoke, who is psychic and moonlights as a pop star. The Sky Marshal's hit "It's A Good Day to Die" can be seen in its extended version in the bonus features. Speaking of the bonus features, there are two audio commentaries, one by the writer/director Ed Neumeier and actors Casper Van Dien and Jolene Blalock, the other by Ed Neumeier again and also by the visual effects supervisor and the producer. That the cast and crew have the gall to be self-congratulatory in their comments boggles my mind a bit. But, in a weird way, props to them for being so audacious in turning a blind eye to what's really what. I guess, in their defense, what else could you expect them to say? That this movie is earth-shatteringly messed-up and you shouldn't see it? There are two featurettes: "Evolution: The Bugs of Starship Troopers 3: Marauder," focusing on the bug special effects, and "Enlist! Marauder' Mobile Infantry," the Making Of segment, spotlighting the cast.STARSHIP TROOPERS 3: MARAUDER isn't quite HENRY V. Not when the motivational speeches here go along the lines of  "You know what to do. Get in there and kill them all!" or that old chestnut "C'mon, you apes! Do you wanna live forever?" I read the Heinlein novel (Starship Troopers) and really liked it. And I thought that the first STARSHIP TROOPERS was just great, never mind that the critics panned it or that it never made huge box office duckets. Going in, I suspected MARAUDER was going to be weak, and it is. It doesn't even qualify as a guilty pleasure.And yet it's not as stinky as HERO OF THE FEDERATION, so that badge, at least, this film could wear very proudly.Irregardless, Johnny Rico rocks!

reviewText: STARSHIP TROOPERS 3: MARAUDER is a direct to DVD movie based loosely on a world and characters created by Robert A. Heinlein in his classic sci-fi adventure novel STARSHIP TROOPERS.  While this movie is neither high budget nor high art, it is a very entertaining way to spend an evening at home. Now, Johnny Rico will truly be the hero that Heinlein wrote.  STARSHIP TROOPERS 3: MARAUDER is well worth seeing, especially for that reason.  Recommended.

reviewText: The war against humanity is at its greatest peak. The planet Roku San is at its harshest point. With military support waning, soldiers dying daily, and with new bugs constantly revealing themselves to the world, how will humanity survive, if not without you? The Federation is currently looking for men and women to help fight this terror. How would you like to be a hero, and how would you like to become a citizen while you're at it?Would you like to know more?STARSHOOP TROOPERS as a series has become infamously known, if only because the second film did nothing to contribute to the first film's storyline. With little hope in mind, I set out to watch STARSHOOP TROOPERS: MARAUDER in the hopes that, somehow, it would be better than the second, and maybe as good as the first.Sadly, disappointment takes the reins and throws me back a step with STARSHIP TROOPERS 3.Set on the planet Roku San and following our original hero, Johnny Rico, the film is soon shown to have little hope when we get to learning about a few of its characters. Johnny Rico, experienced in his newfound years in the military, has always been known to not follow orders, but in the case of death? The sky marshal, one of the most famous men on Earth, is a pop star? And soldiers who, normally, would not become star struck, are enamored in a sky marshal slash singer's presence, often to the point of completely disobeying orders and ignoring outside threat? What has the series come too, if not a total cheese factor?Sadly, this doesn't let up anytime soon. With a plot mainly following an offcast, Angelina Jolie-lookalike actress named Jolene Blalock as she leads a small group of individuals across the desert of Roku San, the film ultimately falls low as it devolves into an exaggerated attempt of a science-fiction movie.PROS:- Some actors. Jolene Blalock played her character extremely well, as did Marnette Patterson as Holly Little. I also have to give the man who played Johnny Rico credit for contributing to this film. I don't know how much they paid him, but hopefully enough to substantiate his time in playing in a very bad, very underdeveloped movie.The long, long list of cons:CONS:- The CGI. Given that the first film was made in 1997, it was amazingly disappointing that the CGI was so bad. Given the advancement in computer graphics technology, you would think that a film would at least TRY to live up to the standards as its 1997 counterpart. Nope--it didn't. There's no need to think that anymore.- The acting. The majority of the acting was littered with poor actors and actresses. Overemphasized, unamphasized, not emphasized at all--I found very few of the actors to be worth watching. I couldn't help but cringe at the way some of them played their characters, and at the way several of them were portrayed. Military men and women don't follow what we, as individuals, would think they would, marshals and officers order troops around in inane, nonsensical patterns, and soldiers throw themselves over exploding bugs when they could simply retreat to the back of the room. Valor isn't even an issue here--its stupidity that takes the toll.- The cheese. Yes, I specifically mentioned cheese, if only because it's highly relevant in this movie. Sky Marshals as popstars, soldiers being told they'll be shot if they ask for an autograph, then trying to ask for an autograph, higher-ranking Federation officers not bothering to draw a gun when they're getting mercilessly beat up, then trying to arrest a soldier for getting the assailant off him--there's no short amount of corny action to this movie, as there's no shortage of stupidity that comes with the cheese factor.In all, I couldn't help but wonder what exactly happened to this movie. STARSHIP TROOPERS 2 was a disappointment unto itself, but three?... it's horrible. It's better than 2, if only because it follows the storyline and world building of the first better, but it still doesn't make it a movie worth watching.The STARSHIP TROOPERS franchised should've died after the first one was made. MARAUDER should quickly die a slow, horrible death, if only because it tarnishes the original to the point of disappointment. I was excited to see this, despite the warnings several of my friends gave me. I definitely won't watch a fourth in this movie. If I even begin to attempt to, I'll remind myself of how horrible two and three were, then push the first movie into the DVD player, if only because the first will always be the only good STARSHIP TROOPERS movie.

reviewText: I wanted to like this movie a lot. I loved the first one. I'm having trouble even recalling the second one. But as much as I liked the first, I wanted this one to be just as good. As with most sequels that hit the magic number 3, I was disappointed. STARSHIP TROOPERS 3: MARAUDER does not live up to its namesake.The story is based on the classic Robert Heinlein novel STARSHIP TROOPERS. In it, we learn about an invasion from outer space of aliens that are nothing more than giant bugs. Make that giant spiked deadly bugs. The original film followed the story of Johnny Rico who joined the Space Marines to take on these bugs.Rico (Casper Van Dien) is still alive and kicking bug butt in outer space as this film begins. The Federation is still pushing its agenda of recruiting soldiers to fight this war with the intent of driving the bugs back to where they came from. To do so, they've taken on a new military leader, Sky Marshall Anoke (Stephen Hogan). Anoke is a psychic and singer whose new hit single inspires the masses to take up arms against the bugs.The Sky Marshall is about to touch down on the farming planet that Ricco and his men are currently protecting, a linchpin to the defenses of the star system. The Sky Marshall's right hand man is Gen. Dix Hauser (Boris Kodjoe) who is all set to marry the pilot of their spacecraft, Lola Beck (Jolene Blalock). It turns out the Ricco and Beck are old comrades which leads to Hauser making a few decisions based on jealousy instead of leadership skills.When someone turns off the juice to the forts fortifications, the bugs over run the base and kill everyone in sight. Beck gets the Sky Marshall off planet while Hauser and Ricco take down as many bugs as possible. In the end, Hauser court marshals Ricco and a hanging is scheduled for interstellar viewing.When word gets back to Hauser that Ricco was innocent, that there is a cover up taking place and that Beck, the Sky Marshall and the crew are being left for bug bait, he breaks Ricco out during the hanging and sends him out with a team that possesses a new weapon that just may turn the tide. A weapon that fans of the novel were hoping to see in the first film.The film features plenty of action and special effects, but these effects are nothing when compared to the original. If you're going to make a sequel, at least have the decency to spend the money where it should be spent.The acting level is that of a made for TV movie featured on a cable channel that caters too special interests. In which case Van Dien should feel at home since his staple seems to be those types of film on the Sci Fi network. Which is sad since he showed such promise in the original film. He's not the worst actor working, but his choices leave much to be desired.The other actors hang in there but the dialogue they have is some of the worst, filled with clichés from beginning to end. That in itself is strange since the director/screenwriter for this film is Ed Neumeier who wrote the original as well as the original ROBOCOP. For some reason here, it is the script that is lacking and not so much the delivery by the actors.For me the worst part of the film was the blatant and obvious metaphoric use of storytelling to slam the current political scheme of things. Granted, mistakes have been made, wrong choices can be found everywhere, but not all of them come from one party or the other. Hollywood's belief is that everything military needs to be made fun of or ridiculed. And yet at the same time the need for a strong military is portrayed here as well. The film wants it both ways and does neither justice.So yes, I was disappointed in this film. Is it the worst movie ever made? No. The worst science fiction movie ever made? Again, no. Is it entertaining? Sure. Just don't watch expecting anything as outstanding as the first film. If you have that in mind, you just might enjoy this one.

reviewText: I don't know if Robert E. Heinlein's novel of the same name was quite the neo-fascist vision that Peter Verhoeven created for this film franchise, but it sure was entertaining.  Verhoeven took Heinlein's ideals of citizenship, national pride, and fear of the communist collective and turned it into a multimedia orgy of violence, exploitation, and Big Brother proselytizing. Gone were the mecha suits that made the Troopers famous in anime, comics, and toys - instead the troopers were armed with nothing but helmets, automatic weapons, and their wits against all manner of giant alien bugs.The third installment of this franchise stays true to the spirit of the original movie while attempting to reintroduce the tenets Heinelein originally envisioned from his books.  Johnny Rico (Casper van Diem, the role he originated in the first film) is back, fighting bugs and representing all the heroic ideals of national service in an intergalactic military. Positioned in an outpost that's surrounded by bugs, he is a maverick leader in an otherwise regimented hierarchy of soldiers, not that much different from the warrior bugs who batter the outpost's doors.Complicating matters is the arrival of the handsome General Dix Hauser (Boris Kodjoe) and Captain Lola Beck (Jolene Blalock), a suitable Angelina Jolie stand-in who manages to convey pouty, sexy, and sulky all at the same time.  Beck doesn't seem particularly competent, but then she doesn't wear tight black tank tops for us to admire her competence. Rico, of course, dated her in the past,  which is a bone of contention between Hauser and Rico. Further complicating the mix is Sky Marshal Omar Anoke (Stephen Hogan) a national (intergalactic?) war hero.  He sings, he dances, he kills bugs - Anoke's arrival is as much a publicity stunt as it is a morale booster for the beleaguered troops.All these tangled plots come together when the bugs breach the walls.  Fleeing, the team is scattered to the four corners of the galaxy.  Rico, who does some necessary but insubordinate things to survive during the attack, is tried for treason.  Our war hero leads the others to the holy land in search of a being named Behemecoatyl he claims is God.And that's what distinguishes this Starship Troopers installment from the others that came before it: faith. The third part of the trilogy switches nationalistic fervor with religious fervor. Fascism is replaced by evangelism, in a bizarre plot that could only happen in Starship Troopers. This is heady stuff for a sci-fi war movie.Starship Troopers 3 aims high, but its actors can't quite pull it off.  The actors woodenly deliver lines means to be infused with passion, the CGI is passable but not quite the same level as the original, and the interstitial cuts of media commentary aren't quite as clever.  But then we conclude with a bug vs. mech battle and all is forgiven.You can't ask for much more from a trilogy about interstellar bug hunting.

reviewText: I didn't have high hopes for Starship Troopers 3: Marauder, even though it features the return of Casper Van Dien as Johnny Rico and seemed to be more along the lines of Paul Verhoeven's 1997 original in tone. Combine that with some decent at best CGI effects (and some effects that do look awful), campy acting from Van Dien and Enterprise's Jolene Blalock (who seems to have only been able to afford cologen shots for the first half of the film only as her lips appear to shrink in size), and you get a surprisingly not bad direct-to-DVD three-quel.  All in all, Starship Troopers 3: Marauder is a worthwhile trip for fans of the original film, and is much more satisfying than what you may be expecting.

reviewText: I'm very picky about the quality of movies that I invest time in viewing, and you'll see by my overall Amazon rating that I try to be fair, impartial, and my friends consider my taste in science fiction excellent (although I'm sure someone would answer that by saying taste is purely subjective). Starship Troopers 3: Maurauder is by far one of the finest sci-fi productions made. Released in the year of the most life threatening economic collapse since the Great Depression, perhaps its thunder was eclipsed by a terrible global scale reality that for many required blind faith to survive.Speaking of blind faith, as an agnostic, I believe Marnette Patterson in her role as Holly Little made a convincing argument for the necessity for faith in even technologically advanced intelligent species (such as the future humans fighting a seemingly unstoppable extraterrestrial threat from an insect-like intelligent species of arachnids). Setting aside the argument that faith is rewarded by God, faith is necessary to survive impossible odds and triumph. The character Holly Little exemplified this reality that even the most skeptical atheists do well to embrace. Otherwise, if one is stranded in a place that is deemed "impossible" to escape from, why even try? Why not sit down and wait to die or worse, commit suicide? Faith is often rewarded in the realization of seemingly impossible and astronomical odds that by comparison make the inter-state lottery seem like easy odds by comparison.I won't give it away by critiquing it in detail. I think any sci-fi fan, and those who like excellent acting (of ALL the cast who made this film a Hollywood classic, without intending to single out Marnette as only one of many talented and gifted actors), cinematography, screen writing and rock solid directing may very well find startling epiphanies in viewing this last of the three Starship Troopers (which is a "standalone" film you can watch without seeing the rest!) - just as I did.
summary: Starship Troopers 3: Maurauder is by far one of the finest sci-fi productions ever made

reviewText: As a long-time science-fiction devotee I think this movie is an insult to the genre on a par with Plan 9 From Outer Space.Low budget does not disqualify a movie from being excellent (see Monsters and Ever Since the World Ended for excellent examples).  But it is clear that some producers were cynically out to just make some bucks.The plot is a terrible mashup of Alien Sci-Fi, Big Brother paranoia, and pseudo-religious pablum thrown in.  The movie does not really have anything to say on these worthwhile ideas (contrary to good Sci-Fi), but instead serves these things up, willy-nilly, to "check off the box" for widest marketing impact.The special effects are passable given the low budget, and there is enough action and a few scenes of nudity to keep a frat house audience entertained.  Heinlein must be spinning in his grave.*** Spoiler Alert ****Try to imagine that the citizens of Earth have become so controlled that freedom of speech is accepted as a threat to all.  The military state has taken it upon itself to execute anyone who disagrees with the endless war on the "bugs" (the aliens from the first Starship Troopers).  Imagine further that religion has also become a capital offense.  It appears at first that the movie cannot make up its mind whether it is against the last 10 years of the wars in Afghanistan/Iraq, or if it is in favor of institutionalized religion.  But wait....The military suffers an horrific defeat at the hands of the "bugs" on planet Roku San (the result of treachery we later find out).  A fleet spaceship is also attacked, and an escape pod is launched carrying, among others, the highest ranking member of the military (the mind-reading, rock star fascistic leader known as the Sky Marshall).  The escape pod makes a forced landing on a bug-infested planet.  While awaiting rescue, the survivors alternately bicker about the orders given them by their (non-believing) superior officer, quarrel lamely over religious beliefs, or get picked off by bugs on occasion.  The Sky Marshall lets it be known that he has found religion based on his communication with the brain of one of the bug-leaders - although religion is a capital offense.  All this happens against a background of growing unrest on Earth as protesters, led by the cross-wearing, wheel-chair bound Elmo Gonif, become more vocal and foul-mouthed.  Oh, by the way, gonif is a Yiddish word for "thief" or "cheater" or perhaps "con man".  Were the filmmakers subtly equating liberal/intellectual dissidence with Jewish-ness, while true goodness was equated with Christian acceptance?  The people in power are dressed similarly to Nazi military.I'm sure that some of this was intended as campy tongue-in-cheek Sci-Fi, but there ain't much in the way of laughs or real humor.  You can see that many concerns of the conservative right are on display - government-sponsored anti-religiousness, unpleasant ineffective liberal/intellectuals abusing free speech, the need for an endless crusade that must be waged against a relentless, godless, enemy.  The movie contains these topical elements without using Sci-Fi as a means of actually examining them.  It reminded me of a high school student's hastily written essay homework, containing the important buzz words without knowing what to say about them.Ultimately, the survivors find "true" (Christian) religion and are saved at the last minute by mindlessly repeating a prayer, though the Sky Marshall dies suitably horribly.  Their successful struggle to survive is seen as justification for BOTH the endless war AND for unquestioning adherence to the "true" religion.I bet George Bush and Dick Cheney would love this message, and Heinlein (who became quite conservative) would probably smile at the ultra-conservative message coming from liberal Hollywood.  It's all done hastily and awkwardly.  If the movie did in fact have something meaningful to say, it was obscured and I missed it.This one would have been good as fodder for Mystery Science Theater 3000, but as it is, it's boring, inane, and cynical.  I wasted 92 minutes of my life so you wouldn't have to.If you're in the mood for thought-provoking Sci-Fi, check out "Monsters"

reviewText: Casper Van Dien is back as Rico, hero of the Federation and now a Colonel defending the farm planet of Roku-San.  Unexpectedly, Sky Marshall Anoke comes to the planet for a visit.  Anoke is one of the more ridiculous characters in any of the films.  A pop-star Military Commander who sings songs glorifying the war effort and hoping to inspire new recruits.  He's also a telepath who has been communicating with the brain bug captured in the first film.  Joining Anoke is Rico's friends General Dix Hauser, and Captain Lola Beck (Blalock).  Soon after the Sky Marshall arrives, all hell breaks loose as the electrified fences fail and bugs storm the outpost forcing an evacuation.Beck, the Sky Marshall, and a few others crash on another planet while Rico is gets the blame for what happened on Roku-San and is sentenced to hang.  He's given a second chance by Dix who wants Rico to take a team of Troopers and attempt to rescue the Sky Marshall but it seems there are those in high places who do not want him rescued.  The planet they are on just happens to be the home of the bug God!The special effects in Starship Trooper 3 are disturbingly bad.  During one of the featurettes, some of the special effects guys talk about how the technology has advanced allowing them to make the film's bugs look better than ever.  Unfortunately they must have been talking about a different movie.  The bugs in Starship Trooper 3 look far worse than they did in the original film and there are far fewer of them.  The first film wasn't great, but there were some fantastic battle scenes with all manner of bugs.  Here, we only really get the standard bugs and in limited quantities.  The special effects look like something produced for the Sci-Fi Channel.Van Dien gets top billing but Blalock gets the most screen time as the tough Captain Beck, trying to keep the Sky Marshall and the rest of the group safe from the bugs.  Blalock simply isn't a strong enough actress to carry a film on her own.  She's damn near emotionless throughout the entire film except when she's berating the Sky Marshall's assistant, Holly, for praying.  On top of that, Jolene has been dipping into the collagen a bit too much.  Her lips look like she's got a catcher's mitt stuff in her mouth and it's a bit ghastly.The film only rolls when Van Dien is onscreen because he plays his character with such over-the-top gusto.  He's campy to the extreme but also great fun.  The Federation news flashes are also a scream as a satire of right-wing, war-worshipping politics as they extol the virtue that it is "a good day to die" as long as you are dying defending the Federation.After one so-so film and two direct-to-video releases, I think it's time we let Mr. Heinlein rest in peace.ExtrasThere are two commentary tracks.  One with Writer/Director Ed Neumeier, producer David Lancaster, and Visual Effects Supervisor Robert Skotak and the second with actors Casper Van Dien and Jolene Blalock."Evolution: The Bugs of Starship Troopers 3: Marauder" featurette"Enlist: Marauder's Mobile Infantry" featuretteExtended version of the music video "It's a Good Day to Die"

reviewText: Johnny Rico (Casper Van Dien) is back in part 3 of the Starship Troopers saga! Following a horrible direct to video sequel, the franchise needed something in order to get people to start watching again and Van Dien certainly does the trick. After our update as to what's going on in their world, we see a transport ship, carrying the Sky Marshall, crash on a seemingly deserted planet. It becomes Johnny Rico's job to mount a rescue and newcomer, Lola Beck's (Jolene Blalock), to keep the Marshall safe. Beck was a major character in the original comics, but was never introduced into the film series until now. Essentially, she is the ultimate bad ass, and makes this movie worth seeing. The story wasn't bad, Van Dien wasn't much more than an extended cameo, in order to get viewers, but it was Jolene Blalock as Lola Beck that makes this movie worth seeing she really was fantastic. It's certainly not the original, but it's much better than the second one. If you're a fan of the series, you won't be disappointed.

reviewText: Here is a good news: in "Starship Troopers 3: Marauder" Casper Van Dien returns as Johnny Rico, now a colonel in charge if his own unit. As you know, he was seen in the original "Starship Troopers" more than 10 years ago and though he looks a bit aged, Casper Van Dien is in good shape as the reliable hero of this sci-fi action. Bad news is, well, I really hate to say this, but they should have spent more on the production designs and special effects.This is the first film for director Edward Neumeier (who also wrote the script for all the "Starship Troopers" films including this one and "RoboCop") His script written for "ST3" attempts to cover so many things - battles, intrigues, romances, politics and even religion - that it becomes unfocused with bits of this, bits of that, and some of ideas that could have been developed. You will see "Marauder," a powered mobile military machine worn by Federation soldier, but the battle scenes involving this new deadly weapon need better effects.I almost forgot to tell you the story. It is complicated, but basically it begins with the humans' battles against warrior bugs, but it gradually becomes more about the internal conflicts among humans. Rico is not allowed to act like a hero until the very end (his screen time is comparatively short), and that means, if you are looking for the heavy combats and bloody battles between humans and bugs as seen in the first installment of Paul Verhoeven-directed "Starship Troopers," you will be disappointed.The new film shows us more about the politics of Federation, introducing an enigmatic character Admiral Enolo Phid (Amanda Donohoe, "Snake Lady" of Ken Russell's cult film "The Lair of the White Worm"), who might or might not be Rico's adversary. Resistance groups and Federation's draconian reaction to them are also depicted along with a propaganda song "A Good Day to Die" (which is a big hit, according to the film), but the new additions are not as impressive as the darkly funny newsreels seen in Verhoeven's original.I didn't hate the film, and actually I like the song. It is much better than "Starship Troopers 2." The third film, however, needs something more, either budget or Paul Verhoeven's knowingly over-the-top style.
summary: Johnny Rico Is Back! So Where Is Paul Verhoeven?

reviewText: The original STARSHIP TROOPERS movie was a decent, though somewhat campy flick. It brought to life some of the characters from Robert Heinlein's classic sci-fi book, but it failed to express many of the deeper messages in the book.  That film wasn't a blockbuster success, but did gain cult status when it was released to VHS and a few years later to DVD. There was enough interest in it that a direct-to-DVD sequel was produced a few years later, STARSHIP TROOPERS 2: HERO OF THE FEDERATION.  Other than the basic concept of humans being in a galactic conflict against a race of giant bugs and having the same screenwriter, that movie had nothing in common with the first.Recently, STARSHIP TROOPERS 3 was released.  The film is set a few years after STARSHIP TROOPERS 2. The battle between the bugs and humans is still raging at seems at a standstill with no end in sight.  Under command of Col. Johnny Rico (Casper Van Dien) The Mobile Infantry has built a base in the outpost farming colony of Roku San.  The leading officer of Earth's military, Sky Marshal Omar Anoke (Stephen Hogan) makes a "surprise" visit and inspection to Roku San.  During the Sky Marshal's visit the Mobile Infantry's HQ experiences a massive power failure and the bugs break in and cause chaos.  The Sky Marshal escapes, but the casualties are high and Johnny Rico is blamed. He's brought to trial and sentenced to die. Meanwhile, the Sky Marshal and crew are attacked and crash land on an unexplored planet.  Bugs are spotted, but the crew discovers that another part of the ship has apparently escaped, too. So, they begin the long march to reunite with them.  The Sky Marshal doesn't seem concern with their predicament and seems jubilant at their dire circumstances, which he says are part of a divine plan. His behavior and actions causes some of the crew to wonder if he's gone insane of if he's actual following a demon and not a divinity.STARSHIP TROOPERS 3: MARAUDER isn't feature film-worthy, but it really isn't too bad for a direct-to-DVD release. Just like the first movie, there is some really cheesy dialogue, but things are much better than the awful script of STARSHIP TROOPERS 2: HERO OF THE FEDERATION. There's more action in this movie than in the last and though the special effects aren't the best, they really aren't all that bad. In overall tone and mood, STARSHIP TROOPERS 3 is much more akin in the Starship Troopers universe than STARSHIP TROOPER 2.Though I didn't think it was remarkable in anyway, I enjoyed watching STARSHIP TROOPERS 3: MARAUDER.  I especially liked that Casper Van Dien had returned to his role as Johnny Rico. I also liked that the film attempt to examine the political system of the Federation without making it boring.  Though different in tone and intent of Heinlein's novel, these themes were more in spirit with the book than the previous movies. I also like that Mech Suits were finally seen and used in the film.  For those who've read the novel, these pieces of equipment are what separates the Mobile Infantry from other divisions of the Federation military and are key to the story. Why filmmakers have waited until now to show/use them is beyond my understanding.The movie does have some rather graphic scenes, such as people getting their heads cut off and blood gushing from vital wounds.  There's also nudity in a scene that's completely unnecessary.The film isn't quite equal to the first movie, but it's a much better movie than STARSHIP TROOPERS 2. It makes for an enjoyable 90 minutes or so of entertainment.The DVD includes a couple of making of featurettes: "Evolution: The Bugs of STARSHIP TROOPERS 3: MARAUDER" & "Enlist: Marauder's Mobile Infantry"; two separate commentaries, and an extended music video of Sky Marshal Omar Anoke's song "It's a Good Day to Die".

reviewText: "Starship Troopers 3" was exactly what I was hoping for - a *worthy* sequel to the first one, which is one of my favorite scifi movies. The satire is laid on a lot thicker this time, probably because so many people missed it the first time around (the singing Sky Marshall made me laugh; also, the use of religion as wartime propaganda is spoofed quite mercilessly).Amazingly, Van Dien has hardly changed since the first one - except that now he's even more buff - and he acts well. He seems to feel comfortable in the role, and it seems like he and the other cast members had a great time filming it.Even the special effects were surprisingly good for such a relatively low-budget movie (even great at times; pretty bad at other times, but we're forgiving), and most important of all, the *story* felt like a good follow-up to the first movie, which was not the case with SST2.Also, I loved the marauder suits, even though they have relatively minor screen time. Which begs the question: what are the odds that there will be a SST 4?
summary: Worthy follow-up to the original movie
